misconceptions.name: Hard-coded grade instead of reading from user
misconceptions.description: The program never reads a numeric grade from the user; instead it assigns a fixed literal value to the grade variable, so the letter grade is not based on user input as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes it is acceptable to test or implement grade calculation using a hard-coded grade value instead of reading the grade from the user.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user for a numeric grade and read it using Scanner (e.g., nextInt or nextDouble), then compute and print the corresponding letter grade based on that input.
symptoms: No prompt like "Enter grade:" appears in the code.
Scanner is only used to read point coordinates, not the grade.
The grade variable is assigned a constant 95.0 rather than being read from input.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely focusing on practicing conditional logic in isolation and not integrating it with proper user input handling for the specific task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hard-coded grade assignment with a prompt and a Scanner call, e.g., print "Enter grade: " and then use input_scanner.nextDouble() (or nextInt()) to read the user's grade into the grade variable.
related_concepts: Reading numeric input from the keyboard
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is an explicit hard-coded assignment to grade and no Scanner call or prompt related to grades anywhere in the program.

evidence.note: The grade is set to a constant 95.0 and is never read from the user, so the program does not "read a numeric grade (0-100)" as required.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Overlapping grade ranges for A and B using separate if statements
misconceptions.description: The student uses independent threshold checks (grade >= 90 and grade >= 80) without upper bounds or else-if, so some grades (e.g., 95) will satisfy both conditions and produce multiple letter outputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that checking grade >= 90 for A and grade >= 80 for B in separate if statements will correctly assign exactly one letter grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Grade ranges must be mutually exclusive, typically implemented with if/else-if chains or explicit upper bounds (e.g., grade >= 90 && grade <= 100 for A, else-if grade >= 80 for B), so that each valid grade maps to exactly one letter.
symptoms: For a grade of 95, both the A and B conditions are true since 95 >= 90 and 95 >= 80.
The code uses multiple standalone if statements instead of an if/else-if chain for mutually exclusive ranges.
No upper bounds are specified for the A and B ranges.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how separate if statements interact and of the need for mutually exclusive Boolean conditions when mapping ranges to a single category.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the conditions to an if/else-if chain and/or add upper bounds, for example: if (grade >= 90) {...} else if (grade >= 80) {...}, so that grades satisfying the A condition are not also checked against the B condition.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly uses grade >= 90 and grade >= 80 as separate ifs, which will both be true for any grade >= 90, leading to multiple outputs.

evidence.note: For grade values >= 90, both conditions are true, so the program prints both "A" and "B" instead of only the correct single letter grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Overlapping grade ranges for C and D using separate if statements
misconceptions.description: Similar to A and B, the C and D grade checks are implemented as independent threshold conditions (grade >= 70, grade >= 60) without upper bounds or else-if, causing overlapping ranges and potentially multiple letter outputs for a single grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes they can determine C and D grades by separately checking grade >= 70 and grade >= 60, assuming only one relevant letter grade will be printed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: C and D ranges must be mutually exclusive and ordered correctly, typically with else-if and/or upper bounds (e.g., else-if grade >= 70 for C, else-if grade >= 60 for D) so that each grade results in exactly one letter.
symptoms: The conditions for C and D are written as separate if statements: grade >= 70 and grade >= 60.
A grade of 75 will satisfy both grade >= 70 and grade >= 60 along with the C condition, and in combination with previous conditions can lead to multiple letters printed.
There is no single 'exactly one branch' structure for 70–79 vs. 60–69.
misconceptions.root_cause: Same misunderstanding as for A and B: the student does not enforce mutual exclusivity among grade ranges and does not recognize the need for else-if or upper bounds.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Place the C and D conditions into the same if/else-if chain used for A and B, e.g., if (grade >= 90) {A} else if (grade >= 80) {B} else if (grade >= 70) {C} else if (grade >= 60) {D} else {F}.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The pattern of separate threshold checks for grade >= 70 and grade >= 60 repeats the flawed approach used for A and B, clearly leading to overlapping ranges.

evidence.note: Because these are independent ifs with only lower bounds, a grade like 75 or 65 will satisfy multiple conditions across C and D (and possibly higher letters), resulting in multiple outputs.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Multiple letters printed and missing required output label
misconceptions.description: The grade-to-letter mapping does not ensure that exactly one letter grade is printed for each numeric grade, and it omits the required "Letter grade: " label in the output.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to think that printing raw letters ("A", "B", etc.) via separate if statements is sufficient to meet the required grade calculator output.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should print exactly one letter corresponding to the numeric grade, typically with the format "Letter grade: X" as shown in the sample run, ensuring a one-to-one mapping between numeric grade and output.
symptoms: For some grades (e.g., 95), the program will print multiple letters ("A", "B", "C", "D").
The printed output is just the letter (e.g., "A") without the prefix "Letter grade: ".
The mapping from numeric grade to output is not a single, clear result for each input.
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete understanding of the specification for the program's output format and of the need for mutually exclusive conditions in a classification problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use an if/else-if/else chain so that only one letter is printed, and prepend the label as in the spec, e.g., System.out.println("Letter grade: " + letter); or directly inside each branch.
related_concepts: String formatting and output in Java
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly prints raw letters using multiple independent if statements and does not match the sample format "Letter grade: B".

evidence.note: These separate if statements can lead to multiple lines of output for one grade and they print only the letter without the required "Letter grade: " prefix.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Sequential Independent If statements for grade ranges (Shadowing)
misconceptions.description: The student uses a series of independent 'if' statements (instead of 'if-else if-else') to check grade ranges. Since the checks are only for the lower bound (e.g., `grade >= 90`, `grade >= 80`, etc.), a grade that satisfies the first condition (e.g., 95) will also satisfy all subsequent conditions (>= 80, >= 70, >= 60), causing multiple letter grades to be printed, leading to incorrect output.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that a series of non-nested 'if' statements can be used to check mutually exclusive ranges, or they do not realize that satisfied conditions do not prevent subsequent ones from being checked and executed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Conditional logic for mutually exclusive ranges (like grade scales) must use 'if-else if-else' structure or incorporate compound boolean expressions (e.g., `(grade >= 80) && (grade < 90)`) to ensure only one block executes.
symptoms: Multiple letter grades are printed for a single numeric grade input.
A grade of 90 or more prints 'A', 'B', 'C', and 'D'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of the flow control provided by independent 'if' statements versus 'if-else if' constructs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: To ensure only one letter grade is printed, use `else if` for the subsequent checks after the first `if` statement.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: It is a clear pattern of using multiple independent `if` statements for mutually exclusive ranges, which is a common and severe error in implementing grade calculations.

evidence.note: The lack of `else` or `else if` means that for a grade of 95, it will print A, B, C, and D, failing the task.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded value instead of input
misconceptions.description: The student hardcodes the grade variable (`double grade = 95.0;`) instead of reading a numeric grade from the user as required by the problem description and captured in the 'Reading numeric grade input' rubric task. The existing code reads 4 coordinates for a different, unrelated problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes assigning a static value to the variable is sufficient for practicing the conditional logic, or they intentionally skipped the input requirement for the grade calculation section.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading the grade from the user using the previously created `Scanner` object (e.g., `double grade = input_scanner.nextDouble();`).
symptoms: The program always calculates the grade for 95.0 regardless of user interaction (in the relevant section of the code).
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to address the prompt's requirement to 'read a numeric grade (0-100)'.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hardcoded initialization of the `grade` variable with a `Scanner` call to read user input.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The line `double grade = 95.0;` clearly shows a hardcoded value used for the grade calculation, directly ignoring the requirement to read the input.

evidence.note: Grade is hardcoded instead of being read from standard input.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing upper bounds in conditional chain
misconceptions.description: The student uses a chain of independent if statements without upper bounds, causing multiple conditions to be true simultaneously. When grade=95, both 'A' and 'B' are printed because both `grade >= 90` and `grade >= 80` evaluate to true.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that using sequential if statements will automatically prevent earlier matches from executing subsequent conditions, or that the order of conditions will naturally filter grades into exclusive categories.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When using independent if statements, ALL conditions are evaluated regardless of previous matches. To create mutually exclusive ranges, use if-else-if chains (e.g., `if (grade >= 90) ... else if (grade >= 80) ... else if ...`) or add upper bound conditions (e.g., `if (grade >= 90 && grade <= 100)`).
symptoms: Multiple letter grades printed for a single input (e.g., both 'A' and 'B' for grade 95)
Output does not match expected single letter grade
All grades >= 60 print multiple letters
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how multiple independent if statements execute. The student may have confused the behavior with switch statements or if-else-if chains where only the first matching block executes.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the chain of independent if statements with if-else-if statements: `if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } else if (grade >= 70) { ... } else if (grade >= 60) { ... } else { ... }`
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the bug is clearly observable: the code explicitly uses 5 independent if statements without any else clauses or upper bounds, which will cause multiple conditions to be true for any grade >= 60, producing multiple outputs instead of a single letter grade.

evidence.note: All conditions are independent if statements. For grade=95, conditions on lines 46 and 47 both evaluate to true, causing both 'A' and 'B' to print.

misconceptions.name: Grade input not read from user
misconceptions.description: The program does not read the numeric grade from user input. Instead, it uses a hardcoded grade value (95.0) on line 45, completely ignoring what the user enters. The rubric explicitly requires reading the grade as input from the user.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the hardcoded grade variable satisfies the requirement, or may have intended to add user input but forgot to implement it.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use Scanner to read the grade from user input (e.g., `System.out.print("Enter grade: "); double grade = input_scanner.nextDouble();`) rather than using a hardcoded value.
symptoms: Program never prompts user to enter a grade
Output does not depend on user input for the grade
Grade value is always 95.0 regardless of what user types
misconceptions.root_cause: The student may have been practicing the grade-checking logic independently (as indicated by the comment on lines 42-44) and forgot to integrate the user input reading into the solution.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add input prompts before the grade checking logic: `System.out.print("Enter grade: "); double grade = input_scanner.nextDouble();`
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The code explicitly declares `double grade = 95.0;` with a hardcoded value on line 45, and there is no Scanner call to read a grade from the user. This directly contradicts the rubric requirement to read numeric grade input.

evidence.note: Grade is hardcoded to 95.0 instead of being read from user input via Scanner.
The Scanner is used for the distance calculation problem (unrelated to Q3), but not for reading the grade for Q3.

misconceptions.name: Grade value hard-coded instead of read from user
misconceptions.description: The program never reads a numeric grade from the user; instead, it assigns grade = 95.0 directly, so the grade calculation is not based on user input as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can practice the grade-checking logic by assigning a literal like 95.0 to grade instead of reading the grade from the keyboard.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user to enter a numeric grade (0–100) and read that value using the Scanner (e.g., input_scanner.nextInt() or nextDouble()); the letter grade must be computed from this user-provided value.
symptoms: The program never prompts for a numeric grade from the user.
The grade variable is always 95.0 regardless of any user input.
The letter grade output cannot change based on user-entered grades.
misconceptions.root_cause: Focusing on practicing conditional logic separately from the full problem specification and not integrating user input for the grade.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hard-coded grade = 95.0 with a Scanner read, e.g., prompt with "Enter grade: " and then use grade = input_scanner.nextDouble(); before the if-statements.
related_concepts: Using variables to store user input
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only grade value in the program is a literal assignment (grade = 95.0) and there is no Scanner call to read a grade from the user.

evidence.note: The grade is assigned a constant value (95.0) and never read from the Scanner, so the program does not take a numeric grade input from the user.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Non-exclusive grade conditions without upper bounds
misconceptions.description: The grade-to-letter mapping uses five independent if statements that only check lower bounds (>= for A–D, < for F) and no upper bounds, so multiple letter grades can be printed for one numeric grade and the specified ranges (e.g., 80–89 for B) are not enforced.
misconceptions.student_belief: As long as each letter grade checks that grade is at least its minimum threshold (e.g., grade >= 80 for B), it will correctly decide which single letter to print.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Grade ranges must be mutually exclusive and match the specification: A is 90–100, B is 80–89, C is 70–79, D is 60–69, and F is below 60. This is typically implemented with an if–else-if–else chain and explicit ranges using both lower and upper bounds (e.g., grade >= 80 && grade <= 89) or by ordering conditions so only one branch can execute.
symptoms: For a grade like 95.0, the program satisfies grade >= 90, 80, 70, and 60, so it prints A, B, C, and D instead of only A.
No condition checks the upper bounds for B (89), C (79), or D (69), so ranges do not match the problem statement.
F is implemented as a separate if instead of a default else, so it is not clearly the catch-all for remaining grades.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding how independent if statements and Boolean range checks interact, and not realizing that overlapping conditions can all be true without else-if to make them mutually exclusive.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the five independent if statements into an if–else-if–else ladder with explicit, non-overlapping ranges, for example: if (grade >= 90 && grade <= 100) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } ... else { System.out.println("F"); }.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All five conditions are written as separate ifs using only >= or < without && or else-if, which guarantees overlapping true conditions for high grades; this directly contradicts the required 80–89/70–79/60–69 ranges.

evidence.note: Five independent if-statements only check lower bounds (>=) for A–D and <60 for F, so a grade like 95.0 satisfies all first four conditions and prints multiple letters, and no 80–89/70–79/60–69 upper bounds are enforced.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoding Input Value
misconceptions.description: The student hardcoded the grade value (95.0) instead of using the provided Scanner to read the grade from user input, failing to meet the core requirement of reading input.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is sufficient to test the grading logic with a hardcoded value, or the student forgot to replace the hardcoded placeholder with the input reading logic.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must prompt the user and read the grade value using the Scanner object (e.g., `input_scanner.nextDouble()` or `input_scanner.nextInt()`).
symptoms: Program output is always the same, regardless of user input (for the grade check portion).
The logic for the grade calculation uses a literal value (95.0) instead of a variable initialized by user input.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to connect the input requirement (rubric task) with the existing input mechanism (Scanner).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Define the 'grade' variable after prompting the user and initialize it by calling the appropriate method on the `input_scanner` object.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses `double grade = 95.0;` and does not attempt to read input for this specific variable.

evidence.note: The grade is hardcoded to 95.0 instead of being read from standard input.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Nested Conditionals Required (Dangling If)
misconceptions.description: The student used independent `if` statements instead of chained or nested conditional structures (like `if-else if-else`). When a high grade (like 95) is input, it satisfies multiple conditions (`>= 90`, `>= 80`, etc.), causing the program to incorrectly print multiple letter grades (A, B, C, D) instead of just the highest applicable one (A).
misconceptions.student_belief: The sequence of independent `if` statements checks for distinct categories and that checking for >= 90 automatically prevents checking for lower grades, or the student doesn't realize that a single piece of execution flow can satisfy multiple sequential conditions.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Grade ranges are mutually exclusive. To ensure only one range is selected, `if-else if` statements must be used. If independent `if`s are used, then each condition must explicitly check both the lower and upper bounds (e.g., `grade >= 80 && grade < 90`).
symptoms: A single input (e.g., 95) results in multiple outputs (A, B, C, D).
The conditional logic lacks `else if` or explicit upper bound checks.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how non-exclusive independent `if` structures evaluate in a sequential process.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the sequence of independent `if` statements with an `if...else if...else if...else` structure to ensure that once a condition is met, subsequent checks are skipped.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code uses four consecutive independent `if` statements (`if (grade >= 90)`, `if (grade >= 80)`, etc.) which guarantees multiple outputs for any grade 90 or above.

evidence.note: The grading logic uses independent 'if' statements, leading to cascading output (A, B, C, D) for high grades.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded input instead of reading from user
misconceptions.description: The student hardcoded a grade value (95.0) instead of reading input from the user using the Scanner object. The code does not prompt the user for a grade or read keyboard input as required by the problem specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they can skip the input reading step and test the grade-checking logic with a hardcoded value.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read a numeric grade from the user using Scanner (nextInt() or nextDouble()) in response to a prompt, then process that input value through the grade-checking logic.
symptoms: No prompt asking for user input
A hardcoded literal value (95.0) is used instead of reading from Scanner
The program cannot accept different grades as input
misconceptions.root_cause: Student treated this as a practice exercise disconnected from the actual problem requirements (as evidenced by their comment).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a prompt like System.out.print("Enter grade: "); then read the value with grade = input_scanner.nextDouble();
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The hardcoded value is explicitly visible in the code at line 47: double grade = 95.0;

evidence.note: Grade is hardcoded as a literal value instead of being read from user input via Scanner.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Use of independent if statements instead of if-else-if for mutually exclusive conditions
misconceptions.description: The student uses multiple independent if statements to check grade ranges, causing multiple grade letters to print for a single grade value. The conditions are not mutually exclusive; for example, a grade of 95 satisfies >= 90, >= 80, >= 70, and >= 60, so all corresponding grades (A, B, C, D) would print.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that using separate if statements will somehow only print one letter grade, or hasn't considered that multiple conditions can be true simultaneously for the same value.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When conditions should be mutually exclusive (a grade cannot be both A and B), use if-else-if chains or switch statements. For grade 85, only the first true condition (B: >= 80 and < 90) should execute, not all conditions >= 80.
symptoms: Multiple letters print for a single grade input
For grade 95.0, the output would be A, B, C, D (all four print)
Incorrect output that doesn't match the expected single letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how multiple if statements interact. The student did not recognize that all true conditions execute independently, and did not use else-if or add upper bounds to create mutually exclusive ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace with if-else-if structure: if (grade >= 90) ... else if (grade >= 80) ... else if (grade >= 70) ... else if (grade >= 60) ... else ... This ensures only one branch executes.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses five independent if statements (lines 49-53) without any else clauses, and none of the first four conditions include upper bounds, guaranteeing multiple grades print for values >= 60.

evidence.note: All five conditions are independent if statements without else clauses. For grade=95.0, all of lines 49-52 will execute, printing A, B, C, D.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing upper bounds in grade range conditions
misconceptions.description: The conditions for grades A and B (and C and D) lack upper bounds. For example, 'grade >= 80' for B does not exclude grades 90+, which should be A. The correct condition for B should be 'grade >= 80 AND grade < 90' or handled via if-else-if structure.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that checking only the lower bound is sufficient for defining a grade range, not realizing that grade ranges have both lower and upper limits.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Grade ranges are bounded intervals: B is 80-89, not 80+. The condition must ensure the grade falls within BOTH the lower bound (>= 80) AND upper bound (< 90). This is typically handled via if-else-if chains where earlier conditions exclude higher values, or by explicitly adding upper bounds.
symptoms: Grade ranges are not properly defined as closed intervals
Multiple grade letters print for high values
For grade 95, B prints when it should not (B is only 80-89)
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete understanding of how to define numeric ranges in code. Student only checked the lower boundary without considering the upper boundary.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use if-else-if so earlier conditions prevent later execution: if (grade >= 90) A else if (grade >= 80) B ... Or add upper bound: if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90) B
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The condition 'if (grade >= 80)' on line 50 visibly lacks an upper bound check (should be >= 80 AND < 90 for true B range), and the overall structure doesn't prevent multiple outputs.

evidence.note: Missing upper bound check. For grade=95, this condition is true, so B prints incorrectly. Should be: grade >= 80 && grade < 90 (or use else-if structure).
